body:
Pinging this again. All Python MacOS tests are timing out.

https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_master/11263/config=dbg,language=python,platform=macos/testReport/junit/(root)/tests/py_test/

Seeing this problem again on Linux, dbg
https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_master/13402/config=dbg,language=python,platform=linux/testReport/(root)/tests/py_test/

The non-timeout one I'll get to tomorrow. The timeout ones still require digging into that I've still not yet gotten around to (Python debugger doesn't handle threads and haven't instrumented code, but that's next!). I have a few theories though.

@ctiller Is it well-defined that a server is ready and listening on a port the moment the `grpc_server_start` returns? Else is there any way in core to check whether or not a server has finished spinning up?

We call listen() before grpc_server_start, and start waiting for it to turn
readable when grpc_server_start is called, so off the top of my head I can
think of no reason why it wouldn't be ready. You'd need to be blocking in a
completion queue to notice, of course.

On Wed, Dec 16, 2015 at 10:20 PM Masood Malekghassemi <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> The non-timeout one I'll get to tomorrow. The timeout ones still require
> digging into that I've still not yet gotten around to (Python debugger
> doesn't handle threads and haven't instrumented code, but that's next!). I
> have a few theories though.
> 
> @ctiller https://github.com/ctiller Is it well-defined that a server is
> ready and listening on a port the moment the grpc_server_start returns?
> Else is there any way in core to check whether or not a server has finished
> spinning up?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/3870#issuecomment-165353046.

That... could be it. Would it be sufficient to pluck a bogus tag with immediate deadline (or even a deadline in the past) to let the server finish its waiting?

Alternatively, if a server isn't ready, a call is made to the server, and later the server starts up while the call hasn't timed out yet (... somehow; the parameters for this aren't clear in my head), does the server manage to respond to the call or is it one of those situations where the message is very likely lost in the aether?

The message won't be lost: the bytes for the request will be sitting in a
kernel buffer waiting to be picked up. If it's too long, what could happen
is that the client cancels its connection attempt, and then retries a few
seconds later (and repeat, with exponentially longer waits).

On Wed, Dec 16, 2015 at 11:02 PM Masood Malekghassemi <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> That... could be it. Would it be sufficient to pluck a bogus tag with
> immediate deadline (or even a deadline in the past) to let the server
> finish its waiting?
> 
> Alternatively, if a server isn't ready, a call is made to the server, and
> later the server starts up while the call hasn't timed out yet (...
> somehow; the parameters for this aren't clear in my head), does the server
> manage to respond to the call or is it one of those situations where the
> message is very likely lost in the aether?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/3870#issuecomment-165362383.

Hmm...
- Would it be sufficient to pluck a bogus tag with immediate deadline (or even a deadline in the past) to let the server finish its initial waiting?
- Does the server also retry if the client disappears before the deadline is up? If so, can a situation arise wherein the client calls (call 1), gives up, the server receives that call (call 1), and the client calls again (call 2), the server also receives that call (call 2), and the client and server talk over call 2 but the server is left hanging with call 1 until the deadline passes?

Each call only ever\* goes out on one TCP connection. A bogus pluck or next
will allow the connection to establish. I did exactly this in
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/4482 for similar reasons.
- that might change one day, but I expect it'd be very opt in

On Wed, Dec 16, 2015, 11:15 PM Masood Malekghassemi <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Hmm...
> - Would it be sufficient to pluck a bogus tag with immediate deadline
>   (or even a deadline in the past) to let the server finish its initial
>   waiting?
> - Does the server also retry if the client disappears before the
>   timeout is up? If so, can a situation arise wherein the client calls (call
>   1), gives up, the server receives that call (call 1), and the client calls
>   again (call 2), the server also receives that call (call 2), and the client
>   and server talk over call 2 but the server is left hanging with call 1
>   until the deadline passes?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/3870#issuecomment-165365410.
